{ "background_color": 4210752.0, "on": false, "grid_y": 12.0, "snap_grid": 1.0, "lb_version": "2023.1.1", "background_image": "", "sammi_version": "2023.1.1", "encrypted": false, "adaptive_resizing": 1.0, "unique_id": "20230403200051570050702", "button_list": [ { "color": 105.0, "persistent": 1.0, "text": "!!READ ME FIRST!!", "release_duration": 0.0, "queueable": 0.0, "command_list": [ { "cmd": 4.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 0.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 317.0, "b0": "BEFORE YOU DO ANYTHING ELSE, RUN "INITIALIZE SFTL TEST LAB" WHILE OBS IS RUNNING
---
Also make sure you've grabbed "SFTLTestPack.zip" and unzipped it directly to your SAMMI
installation directory. For example, if SAMMI is in...

C:/Streaming/SAMMI

... unzip this *directly* to C:/Streaming/SAMMI and not a sub-folder.

The Initialize button will ensure that scenes, sources, and INI files are created,
while the files from SFTLTestPack will add necessary files for many of the buttons
included in this deck.
If the file names or folder structures have been changed, certain buttons won't work
properly.

Okay, on with the rest.", "v0": 0.0 }, { "cmd": 4.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 1.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 380.0, "b0": "ABOUT THIS DECK
---
This deck and the buttons included are provided with no warranty or guarantees.

It's not like pressing one is going to make your PC explode, but I'm just a guy
trying to make fun buttons for other people to use in SAMMI. What works for my
environment may not work for everyone else's, and I've only got so many options
for testing. But I hope they work for you, and I hope you have fun with them. <3

Most of these are Twitch related - that's just the nature of the beast right now.
For example, you can't pull the number of YouTube Subscribers you have in the
same way you can pull Twitch Followers. I may look into some YouTube options 
down the line based on interest and feedback, but I'm just one person doing this
in my free time. That said, a lot of the principles that apply to Twitch can also
apply to YouTube with a few adjustments.

Please note that this has been tested with OBS v28 and above. Certain buttons and
effects may run into issues with v27 and below due to changes in OBS between those
two major versions.", "v0": 0.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 2.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 276.0, "b0": "TWITCH ALERTS
---
A variety of alerts for different situations. These have triggers set already,
so you can try triggering them via SAMMI Bridge in OBS to see how they work.

Keep in mind they're extremely basic and for boring reasons that aren't worth
getting into, they lack visual polish. These are meant to show you how the
cookies are made so that you can make your own cookies, rather than being an
out of the box solution.

Some of them include pulling the names of raiders, shoutouts, and more, so
I recommend triggering these via SAMMI Bridge in OBS to see how they work
in action (if you run the button on its own via SAMMI Core, it'll still *run*,
but you'll get lots of text replaced with "undefined").", "v0": 0.0, "comment_color": 16747008.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 3.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 115.0, "b0": "TWITCH SUB GOALS
---
Mostly different types of trackers to see where your current subs are at
as well as sub goals. Realistically you can use the methods described here
to track just about any piece of data Twitch provides, including things
like followers. Go wild!", "v0": 0.0, "comment_color": 10764644.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 4.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 63.0, "b0": "TWITCH COMMANDS
---
Replacements for slash commands as well as some other helpful automations.
Not a ton more to say than that.", "v0": 0.0, "comment_color": 5385234.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 5.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 337.0, "b0": "SECURITY CENTER
---
Automations that can take some pressure off of you when it comes to
moderation needs, particularly when your team is just you.

These tend to be pretty powerful, so instead of having "out of the box"
triggers, I've added information on HOW to set the triggers. That way your
regulars aren't accidentally caught in the crossfire.

Triggers also copy when you copy a button, so keep that in mind if you want
to copy these to your own deck(s) or want to make different buttons for
different purposes, but don't want to set up every single trigger again.

Added Twitch chat security that can be combined with automations to create
a safer streaming environment.
You can also combine these with things like Twitch announcements to let
people know when chat is open and closed.", "v0": 0.0, "comment_color": 3938340.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 6.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 233.0, "b0": "PERSISTENT THING COUNTER
---
A set of buttons that keeps track of a number, and relies on an INI file
to do so. Since SAMMI doesn't keep any information in memory when it's
closed (or crashes, or otherwise), INI files are an easy way to store
information across sessions.

If no INI file exists, there won't be anything to load from, so make sure
any adjustments you make to the INI file and/or folder where it's stored
are updated in SAMMI, too!", "v0": 0.0, "comment_color": 2098242.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 7.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 110.0, "b0": "GEARWORKS
---
Things that are entirely local to SAMMI and OBS, and are not tied to any specific
platform. These are more jumping off points to make your own effects and/or other
miscelaneous automations.", "v0": 0.0, "comment_color": 9551906.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 8.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 233.0, "b0": "TWITCH POINTS
---
Examples of how to modify Twitch Point redeems, such as adding an artificial
cooldown by pausing / unpausing them or changing the point values on the fly.

You'll need to make sure SAMMI "owns" rewards before you can do anything with
them; you can do this from the SAMMI Core by going to
Twitch Connections > Edit Rewards and making dupes of any rewards that SAMMI
doesn't already own. You'll need to go to Twitch directly to delete the
original versions once you make dupes, but you'll still be able to edit
them from Twitch even though SAMMI is the owner.", "v0": 0.0, "comment_color": 12590996.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 9.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 215.0, "b0": "BOT COMMANDS
---
Despite what it says, you only need a second Twitch account for this, no
coding or scripting knowledge required. If you don't want to use a second
account, you can set these up using your primary streaming account, too.

These are commands that are designed to either run in response to a specific
trigger in chat, i.e. "!lurk", or on a timer, such as a message that is sent
to chat every 15 minutes. They're building blocks to make your own channel bot
that's handled via SAMMI instead of via scripting!

Image", "release_duration": 0.0, "queueable": 0.0, "command_list": [ { "cmd": 4.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 0.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 334.0, "b0": "DISPLAY RANDOM IMAGE
---
Gets a random image via one of two methods and displays it on stream. Note that
this displays the image, but at that point it will just sit there. What you do
with it beyond that is up to you.
You can work either of these methods into alerts, Twitch Point redeems, random effects,
and anything else you put your mind to.

There are two methods outlined below: A weighted array, and the Random command. Each one
will have its own section below. Use whichever method best suits your needs!
(Note that if you have both enabled, Option 2: Random will take priority since it's
further down the chain of commands.)

NOTE: Want to display a random VIDEO instead? You can swap "file" (with quotes)
for "local_file" (with quotes) in the Settings (JSON) boxes below. More info on
that here:
https://sammi.solutions/docs/commands/obs-settings", "v0": 0.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 1.0, "vis": 0.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 34.0, "b0": "OPTION 1: WEIGHTED ARRAY
---
Pull down for more info:
Uses an array to allow more precise control over which files are being loaded
and why by setting weights for how likely certain things will come up.
It's a great option if you want to make a rarity roller or want certain things
to come up more or less often compared to others.

A second array and additional inserts with "_weight" added for each array insert are
required to add weights. If Circle is the first insert and you want it to have a weight
of 5, the first weight should be 5.

Weights do not need to add up to 100! You're only setting the odds of how likely
any given option will come up compared to the others. Arrays are cumulative, so
the example below clears the array before re-creating it to keep things tidy.

Finally, name matters - we'll be pulling the selected item from the array as a
variable, so for ease of use, the file name should match as well... unless you
want to use Switch and Case Statements. You'll want to go to the Rarity Roller
to learn how those work.", "v0": 15.0 }, { "cmd": 234.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 2.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "arrayImage" }, { "cmd": 234.0, "obsid": "Main", Image" }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 17.0, "vis": 0.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 1.0, "xpan": 35.0, "b0": "OPTION 2: RANDOM
---
Pull down for more info:
The "Random" command pulls from a value, and that value is saved to a variable that's
then used to determine how an image source in OBS will change. The easiest way to do
this is to have all files in a single location with incrimental numbers - so for the
example below:

1.png, 2.png, 3.png, etc.

If you want to use a naming scheme, like cat1.png, cat2.png, cat3.png, make sure
you put the name *before* the variable, or OBS will attempt to load an image that
doesn't exist.

Keep in mind that the forward slahes (/) around a variable aren't part of the file
structure, so any variable that's used in a path needs to have a forward slash
following it, too.", "v0": 2.0 }, { "b1": "1", "cmd": 77.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 18.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "randomImage", "b2": "4", "v0": 0.0 }, { "b1": "{"file":"/$global.main_directory_slash$/sftltestlab/images//$randomImage$/.png"}", "cmd": 34.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 19.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "Random // Image" } ], "press_type": 0.0, "x": 0.83333333333333337034076748750522, "border": 2.0, "image": "", "triggers": [ ], "group_id": "", "overlappable": 0.0, "init_variable": "", "deck": 16.0, "width": 0.16666666666666657414808128123695, "button_id": "ID349", "button_duration": 0.0, "y": 0.1666666666666666574148081281237, "switch_deck": "", "height": 0.083333333333333342585191871876305, "release_list": [ ], "functions": 65.0, "stretch": 0.0 }, { "color": 9551906.0, "persistent": 1.0, "text": "Image Location
Randomizer", "release_duration": 0.0, "queueable": 0.0, "command_list": [ { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 0.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 209.0, "b0": "IMAGE LOCATION RANDOMZIER
---
Causes an image to move to a random location.

Can be adjusted and customized in a variety of ways to create your own effects.
One example is to combine commands from this button with "Display Random Image"
and an alpha filter in OBS to have a random image fade in at a random location,
then fade back out. You can even add scale and movement, if you want!

As always, there's no real limit on what you can do, so don't be afraid to
experiment.", "v0": 0.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 1.0, "vis": 0.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 35.0, "b0": "XPOS AND YPOS
---
Pull down for more info:
This set of commands uses "Random" to assign a number to a set of variables that will be used later.

Variables: Unless you have a specific reason to change the names, leave the variables as xpos and ypos.
           These are the X (horizontal) and Y (vertical) values that we'll be using later.

Values: You may want to adjust these based on the size of the image or other media you're displaying so
        that it will show up on-screen *based on the positional alignment set in OBS*. For this example,
        assuming your canvas in OBS is 1920x1080, an image that's 300x300 with default "Top Left"
        alignment should be set at 0 minimum and 1620 maximum for xpos, and 0 minimum and 780 maximum
        for ypos. This ensures that the full image will display on screen without being cut off.

(You generally shouldn't need to use "Allow Float". This will allow decimals, which in this case means
OBS will try to use sub-pixel values that aren't relevant here.)", "v0": 4.0 }, { "b1": "0", "cmd": 77.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 2.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 10.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "xpos", "b2": "1620", "v0": 0.0 }, { "b1": "0", "cmd": 77.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 3.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 10.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "ypos", "b2": "780", "v0": 0.0 }, { "b1": "1000", "cmd": 153.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 4.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 10.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "xpos" }, { "b1": "1000", "cmd": 153.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 5.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 10.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "ypos" }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 6.0, "vis": 0.0, "ms": 10.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 33.0, "b0": "CHANGE IMAGE LOCATION

In this example, causes the image to move upward by 50 pixels. If you don't want the image
to move, turn this command off. Alternatively, if you want it to move in another direction,
you can add / subtract from X End and/or Y End. Make sure any simple math you use is
wrapped in (). For example, if you wanted the image to move left 75 pixels,
X End would be: (xpos-75)

Toggle", "release_duration": 0.0, "queueable": 0.0, "command_list": [ { "cmd": 4.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 0.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 271.0, "b0": "SETUP / ABOUT THIS BUTTON
---
This button works as a simple toggle to turn Shield Mode on and off.
           
It relies on an initial variable, which you can see by right
clicking on the button, then going to "Edit Initial Variables".
           
Clicking the button once will immediately turn Shield Mode ON;
clicking it again while SAMMI is still running will toggle
Shield Mode OFF.

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND testing it a few times to make sure it's
working properly before going live. I sincerely hope you never
have to use this, but it's a good option to have ready to go.", "v0": 0.0 }, { "cmd": 24.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 1.0, "v3": { "default": 0.0, "on": 5.0, "off": 2.0 }, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "shieldmode", "v0": 6.0 }, { "b5": "", "b13": "", "b19": "", "b17": "", "b1": "", "b7": "", "b11": "", "b9": "", "b15": "", "b3": "", "cmd": 26.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 2.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 25.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b16": "", "b0": "off", "b18": "", "b4": "", "b12": "", "b14": "", "b2": "", "b8": "", "b6": "", "b10": "", "v0": 2.0, "v2": 1.0 }, { "cmd": 269.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 3.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 25.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "YOUR CHANNEL NAME HERE", "v0": 0.0 }, { "b1": "=", "cmd": 15.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 4.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 25.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "shieldmode", "b2": ""on"" }, { "b5": "", "b13": "", "b19": "", "b17": "", "b1": "", "b7": "", "b11": "", "b9": "", "b15": "", "b3": "", "cmd": 26.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 5.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b16": "", "b0": "on", "b18": "", "b4": "", "b12": "", "b14": "", "b2": "", "b8": "", "b6": "", "b10": "", "v0": 2.0, "v2": 1.0 }, { "cmd": 269.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 6.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 25.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "YOUR CHANNEL NAME HERE", "v0": 1.0 }, { "b1": "=", "cmd": 15.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 7.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 25.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, "b0": "shieldmode", "b2": ""off"" } ], "press_type": 0.0, "x": 0.33333333333333331482961625624739, "border": 2.0, "image": "", "triggers": [ ], "group_id": "", "overlappable": 0.0, "init_variable": "{

(60s)", "release_duration": 0.0, "queueable": 0.0, "command_list": [ { "cmd": 4.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 0.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 182.0, "b0": "SETUP / ABOUT THIS BUTTON
---
If you're running scheduled ads, this should be used ONLY if you plan
on running additional ads outside of your existing schedule. It's NOT
a replacement for scheduled ads and won't offset an upcoming scheduled
ad block.

---
Creates and then pulls from a weighted array, then uses that information to
trigger a Case Statement that prints an alert to SAMMI (the yellow message
in the bottom left of SAMMI Core). You can use this method to trigger any
number of things, including random images, messages to chat, videos to play,
and changing a source, just to name a few common scenarios.

This is secretly me tricking you - yes, you reading this now, thanks for reading,
appreciate you - into using arrays and Switch / Case Statements.
This is a pretty simiple use case of replacing If Statements for complex switches,
and Switch Statements can be used for just about anything where you want different outcomes
to happen based on different inputs. While If Statements are useful for binary situations
where you need one thing or the other to happen (IF this, ELSE that), Switch and Case
Statements allow you to have as many outcomes as you want from a single input.
Enjoy a new, irresponsible amount of power!", "v0": 0.0 }, { "cmd": 5.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 1.0, "vis": 0.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 34.0, "b0": "ARRAYS AND WEIGHTS
---
Pull down for more info:
These commands create two arrays. The first will be the values that we want to
reference later. These can be nearly anything you want, so use a naming scheme
that makes sense to you.

A second array and additional inserts with "_weight" added for each array insert are
required to add weights. In the example below, if Rare is the first insert and you
want it to have a weight of 50, the first weight should be 50.

Weights do not need to add up to 100! You're only setting the odds of how likely
any given option will come up compared to the others. Arrays are cumulative, so
the example below clears the array before re-creating it to keep things tidy.", "v0": 13.0 }, { "cmd": 234.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 2.0, "vis": 1.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 0.0, Pull down for more info:
Uses the value pulled from the array above (stored as arrayRarityVar in this example)
to run a set of commands based on the value pulled.

You can also have a Case Statement called "default" to run a set of commands if the
value pulled from the array doesn't match any of the other Case Statements. This can
be used in a variety of ways; for example, if the end result is to send a message to

from StreamLabs, StreamElements, or Twitch's new Alert Box widget, but
infinitely more customizable. You have complete control over every last

won't work, as SAMMI won't know what it's supposed to pull.

The follower name will only show in places you specify via the
variable. If you don't want to pull this information *at all*,
you can safely disable or delete this set of commands. In the

settings as-is, so experiment to see what works best for your layout.

Are the cooldowns on your Twitch points too predictable? Got people
hovering over the redeem button watching the seconds left, making it
difficult for other people to redeem them?

These commands pause and then unpause a reward based on set times pulled
at random from an array, creating a silent timer with no visible cooldown.
If you want the time to be even more random, you can use a Random
command instead.
(If both are on, Option 2: Random will take priority since it's later.)

This is intended to be used in tandem with a trigger for
Edit Triggers > Twitch Channel Points so that the point redemption itself
triggers the cooldown, making it fully automated.

           want to consider a separate automation that unpauses all rewards when you
           start a stream, start SAMMI, or similar.", "v0": 0.0 }, { "cmd": 5.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 1.0, "vis": 0.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 34.0, "b0": "OPTION 1: ARRAYS

This can require some advanced knowledge of SAMMI to fix
things if any part of it is changed. Also note that this
was tested on v29 and v30 of OBS; v27 or earlier may run
in to problems.

Chaos Control and the Chaos Buttons use a specific naming
scheme to work properly. If any of the variable names or
button IDs are changed, you'll need to adjust Chaos Control
and the Chaos Buttons to match.

Triggering the button too frequently will cause a brief "stutter"
effect since it causes SAMMI to try to run multiple commands at

---
"It's a roller that rolls rollers."
- CodeChannel@Twitch.tv, 2023

Think of this as a button that pushes other buttons in sequence.
By using a SAMMI trigger, such as a Twitch point redeem, this
button will push a series of Chaos Buttons in order. Once it
runs out of buttons, it starts from the beginning again.

Each Chaos Button queues with itself, meaing that the buttons
run independently and can overlap with other buttons so you can
have a train of actions in rapid succession, but still ensure
each redeem is triggered since it's part of an ongoing queue.

It's a great option for making trains of just about any randomized
image, video, and audio combo you can think of. You shouldn't have
to touch anything in this control button unless you want more /
fewer buttons, or if you feel comfortable modifying this on your own.", "v0": 0.0 }, { "cmd": 6.0, "obsid": "Main", "pos": 2.0, "vis": 0.0, "ms": 0.0, "sel": 0.0, "dis": 0.0, "xpan": 34.0, "b0": "THE CHAOS CONTROL ARRAY AND SWITCH/CASE STATEMENTS

triggered after SAMMI starts up, it will create an array due to the
variable returned being "undefined". The same thing happens when all
inserts have been pulled from the array. After the array has been
created, it pulls a variable, and presses the Chaos Button related
to that variable.

Sets two variables - xpos and ypos - that will be used to determine
the horizontal and vertical coordinates of the source in OBS.

OBS defaults to the positional alignment being the top left of an
image, meaning that 0,0 will make something perfectly aligned to
the top left of the screen.

If images are different sizes, determine which ones have the
largest width (X) and height (Y), and subtract those values from
the Maximum Value Allowed for that particular variable. That should
keep the images from being cut off, though you may need to play
with the values a bit.

For this example, images will be 300x300, so the minimum xpos is

Sets two variables - xpos and ypos - that will be used to determine
the horizontal and vertical coordinates of the source in OBS.

OBS defaults to the positional alignment being the top left of an
image, meaning that 0,0 will make something perfectly aligned to
the top left of the screen.

If images are different sizes, determine which ones have the
largest width (X) and height (Y), and subtract those values from
the Maximum Value Allowed for that particular variable. That should
keep the images from being cut off, though you may need to play
with the values a bit.

Pull down for more info:
Just what it says on the tin, sends a message to chat.
/$raidName$/ can be used to auto-fill the name of the channel that raided.
/$raidAmount$/ can be used to auto-fill the amount of raiders that came with them.
/$raidInfo.game_name$/ can be used to auto-fill the category they were streaming under.

A Switch / Case Statement can also be used to return different types of messages based
on the category - for example, if you want a custom message for "Just Chatting", you
can add a Case Statement for "Just Chatting" (no quotes).

The "undefined" Case Statement will provide a message without the title in case SAMMI
can't pull a title, while "default" will run commands that don't match any other Case

pull channel category info if your channel is offline.

create unique messages for specific categories, too.

Pull down for more info:
Sets the current category you're streaming under as well as
the stream title based on the pop-up from earlier. Tags can
also be set as a stringified array, which is particularly useful
if you have a specific set of tags you always use and want to revert
to each time you update your stream info.

Make sure tags are following the correct format:
["Tag1", "Tag2," "Tag3"]

You can have more than 3 tags, but each should be enclosed in quotes,
followed by a comma (except for the final one), and the whole thing
should be wrapped in [brackets].

If you don't want one of these items (Category, Title, Tags) to be
